verses.text: Wisdom reaches mightily from one end of the earth to the other, and governs all things with gentleness.
verses.comment: Here, 'Wisdom' is personified with divine attributes, mirroring ideas found in Proverbs and hinting at the Word of God, who was present at creation (cf. John 1:1-3).

verses.text: I loved her and sought her from my youth; I desired to take her for my bride and became enamored by her beauty.
verses.comment: The language of love and union with Wisdom foreshadows the intimate relationship God calls believers to have with His truth and His Spirit.

verses.text: She glorifies her noble birth by living with God, for the Lord of all loves her.
verses.comment: Wisdom here is described as being with God, paralleling the Son's unique relationship with the Father as seen in John’s Gospel.

verses.text: For she teaches the understanding of God, and chooses his works.
verses.comment: Wisdom is shown as the means by which God’s will is made known, anticipating the revelation of God's will through the incarnate Word.

verses.text: If riches are desired in life, what is richer than Wisdom, who is the cause of everything that exists?
verses.comment: Echoes Proverbs' teaching that spiritual riches surpass material wealth. Aligns with Christ’s teaching: 'Seek first the kingdom' (Matt. 6:33).

verses.text: If understanding is at work, who among men is a better artisan than Wisdom?
verses.comment: Presents Wisdom as the ultimate source of skill and knowledge, showing the value of aligning one's intellect with divine truth.

verses.text: If someone seeks righteousness, her labors produce virtues; for she teaches self-control and prudence, justice and courage, and nothing in life is more useful than these.
verses.comment: The four virtues mentioned here became known as the 'cardinal virtues.' Early Christians held these in high regard as the foundation for a godly life.

verses.text: If anyone desires broad experience, she knows what is old and what is to come; she understands the subtleties of words and the solving of riddles; she knows the signs and wonders in advance, and the unfolding of times and seasons.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s knowledge includes prophecy and interpretation. This is reminiscent of Christ opening the Scriptures to His disciples (Luke 24:27).

verses.text: Therefore I resolved to take her into my home, knowing that she would give me wise counsel and comfort in troubles and grief.
verses.comment: Receiving Wisdom into one’s home parallels the New Testament theme of God dwelling with His people by the Spirit (John 14:23).

verses.text: Because of her, I will have glory among the people, and honor in the presence of the elders, though I am young.
verses.comment: Wisdom leads to true honor, even from youth, echoing how Jesus grew in wisdom and favor before God and man.

verses.text: I shall be found astute in judgment, and be admired in the sight of rulers and kings.
verses.comment: Wisdom brings influence; this is seen in biblical figures like Joseph and Daniel, who stood out in foreign courts thanks to divine wisdom.

verses.text: When I am silent, they will wait for me; when I speak, they will pay attention; if I speak at length, they will put their hands over their mouths.
verses.comment: The reverence attached to Wisdom reflects the respect given to those who have received divine understanding.

verses.text: Through her, I shall become immortal, and leave an everlasting memory for those who come after me.
verses.comment: The immortality attributed to Wisdom prefigures the life everlasting promised through union with Christ, who is the bread of life.

verses.text: I shall rule over peoples, and nations will be subject to me; terrible rulers will be filled with fear when they hear of me; among the people I shall show myself good, and in war courageous.
verses.comment: This verse depicts Wisdom’s ability to grant consistent virtue in both peace and conflict, a theme fulfilled in Christ's power over nations (Rev. 12:5).

verses.text: When I enter my house, I shall find rest with her, for living with her is free from bitterness, and sharing life with her brings no regret, only joy and happiness.
verses.comment: True fulfillment and peace are found in Wisdom, foreshadowing the rest promised in God’s presence (cf. Heb. 4:9-10).

verses.text: Thinking about her each day, and having fellowship with her, brings no bitterness, but only joy and gladness.
verses.comment: Constant meditation on divine truth leads to enduring joy, mirroring the Psalms' delight in God's law and the New Testament’s teaching on constant prayer (1 Thes. 5:17).

verses.text: When I considered these things inwardly and reflected on them in my heart, I realized that immortality is found in being kin to Wisdom,
verses.comment: Wisdom is linked with eternal life, a theme revealed in Christ, who is both Wisdom and the Life (cf. 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: and deep satisfaction in her friendship, inexhaustible wealth in the work of her hands, understanding in daily conversation with her, and great reputation in sharing her company. I realized that pursuing Wisdom leads to all these gifts.
verses.comment: True fulfillment, honor, and spiritual riches come through a deep relationship with wisdom, which echoes the New Testament call to union with Christ.

verses.text: As a child, I was of good disposition, and my soul was given a noble inheritance;
verses.comment: The mention of a noble soul before birth highlights the value of God’s gift in the soul, echoing biblical affirmations of God’s care from the womb.

verses.text: or rather, being good, I had entered an undefiled body.
verses.comment: This subtle reference to an 'undefiled body' suggests the importance of holiness from one’s earliest moments, connecting to the sanctity of human life.

verses.text: But I knew that I could not obtain Wisdom unless God gave her to me—and this itself was a mark of understanding: to know from whom this gift comes. So I turned to the Lord and earnestly prayed to Him, with all my heart I said:
verses.comment: The author recognizes Wisdom as a gift from God, attainable through humble prayer. This anticipates Christ’s teaching about persistent prayer and receiving the Spirit (Luke 11:13).
